diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +195,199 @@#### I'm writing a definition that depends on another definition. Should I use `<reference types="" />` or an import?

If the module you're referencing is an written as an external module (uses `export`), use an import.
If the module you're referenceing is an ambient module (uses `declare module`, or just declares globals), use `<reference types="" />`.

comments.body: I don't think we want this entry
Actually, I believe we do. This prevents someone from inadvertently trying to publish the package. Our types publisher ignores this field when it generates the actual package.json file.

Yeah, it doesn't work without this field. The linter complains with:
```
package.json should set `"private": true`
```
this is the libraryName change.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +172,176 @@- `asOfVersion`: A stub will be published to `@types/foo` with this version. Should be higher than any currently published version.
- `sourceRepoURL`: This should point to the repository that contains the typings.
- `libraryName`: Name of npm package that replaces the Definitely Typed types. Usually this is identical to "typingsPackageName" so you can omit it.

Any other packages in Definitely Typed that referenced the deleted package should be updated to reference the bundled types. To do this, add a `package.json` with `"dependencies": { "foo": "x.y.z" }`.

comments.body: Thanks! Hope this is going to be enough to stop people adding themselves too soon ü§û

Yeah, I'm curious what, if anything, should be done for existing packages. In practice on `aws-lambda` I've mostly just seen that most pinged users never respond, so I'm not that concerned, but maybe they're all just quietly fuming at the spam?
As one of those `aws-lambda` folks, I'm happy for the spam, though you seem to smash through the requests @simonbuchan before I ever get around to them. üòÉ

Having an opinion had never been a problem for me! But feel free to toss in a second review, even if it's just a empty accept: I'm a bit concerned about my random quirks being gospel for such a popular package.

Yeah, it's not much different from now than before (though maybe because PRs don't need to be delayed by us getting round to it, maybe there could be more) 

Part of our internal chat which trigger this PR covered idle module owners - IMO, I think they're fine to stay as that, but there's probably a space to include docs on how to remove yourself. It's hard though because putting that on a new PR's chat messages feels a bit weird, but maybe it could be in this message  https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/44942#issuecomment-631774581 as a disclosure section 

e.g. 

<details>
    <summary>Getting too many notifications? </summary>
    how to remove yourself
</details>

Yeah, that seems reasonable.
The other case the had been a problem I've seen was people opening issues for a package getting daunted by the number of owners and either not mentioning anyone or only picking a few. It would be nice if the bot could handle this, but for now having fewer owners is a decent mitigation. But DT issues are weird in a few ways

@orta If it remains an issue, I think it would be great if the bot could leave a danger-like comment saying ‚Äúplease verify that you intended to sign-up as maintainer and get pinged for each issue/PR‚Äù. I did that manually for a while and it seemed to make half the people realize what it meant and saying ‚Äúoh no thanks‚Äù. I stopped doing it, though, too tiresome and I feel bad for letting a PR sit 36 hours because of back and forth across a ~12 hour time zone difference.

comments.body: Should the example and notes below be moved to the package.json section?

I thought about that and am happy to go either way. My thoughts were
1. I decided it belonged with "Removing a package". The steps in that section are less followable without it and it doesn't contribute much to the new "package.json" section. Both sections explain `allowedPackageJsonDependencies.txt`.
2. Not having a strong indication in favor of editing it, I opted to minimize this change. Those sections can be reorganized or combined subsequently, and promoting the FAQ entry is neutral at worst, I think?

I can live with that.  My thinking was mostly that I would look for package.json info in the corresponding section (which is not the case for an FAQ entry) and might be annoyed to discover that it was elsewhere.  However, as you point out, the sections seem to have different goals and the example makes sense here.

#### I want to use features from very new TypeScript versions.

comments.body:
It might be worth adding something like "If your package depends on packages that need an `npm install`, you can `npm run test-all` *first* to do that."

But I'm not sure the extra clutter is justified.

I also figured this was good advice, but if you edit _any_ files then `test-all` doesn't work:

```
> definitely-typed@0.0.3 test-all
> node node_modules/@definitelytyped/dtslint-runner/dist/index.js --path .

Error: 'git diff' should be empty. Following files changed:
types/yaireo__tagify/index.d.ts
    at Object.getDefinitelyTyped (/Users/ortatherox/dev/typescript/DefinitelyTyped/node_modules/@definitelytyped/definitions-parser/dist/get-definitely-typed.js:22:15)
    at async Object.prepareAffectedPackages (/Users/ortatherox/dev/typescript/DefinitelyTyped/node_modules/@definitelytyped/dtslint-runner/dist/prepareAffectedPackages.js:15:16)
    at async Object.runDTSLint (/Users/ortatherox/dev/typescript/DefinitelyTyped/node_modules/@definitelytyped/dtslint-runner/dist/main.js:32:11)
```

We could treat this as a bug in test-all? If we do then we can make a dupe of this command called `test-changes` which is a lot more logical for someone fresh to the rpeo
